greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of squarefree numbers in the reduced residue system of n.
comment: Number of positive squarefree numbers <= n that are relatively prime to n.
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
Steven R. Finch, Unitarism and Infinitarism, February 25, 2004. [Cached copy, with permission of the author]
formula: Let s(n) = Sum_{k=1..n} a(k). Then s(n) is asymptotic to C*n^2 where C = (3/pi^2)*alpha and alpha = prod ( 1 - 1/(p*(p+1) ) = 0.7044422009... [From discussions in Number Theory List, Apr 06 2004]
a(n) = Sum_{i=1..n} mu(A007947(n)*i)^2, where mu is the Moebius function (A008683). - _Ridouane Oudra_, Jul 27 2019
example: n=15, there are A000010(15)=8 residues: 1, 2, 4=2^2, 7, 8=2^3, 11, 13 and 14; six of them are squarefree: 1, 2, 7, 11, 13 and 14, therefore a(15)=6.
maple: with(numtheory): rad := n -> mul(p, p in factorset(n)):
program: (PARI) a(n)=my(s=1); forfactored(k=2,n-1, if(vecmax(k[2][,2])==1 && gcd(k[1],n)==1, s++)); s \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Nov 05 2017
(MAGMA) [&+[MoebiusMu(&*PrimeDivisors(k)*i)^2:i in [1..k]]: k in [1..65]]; // _Marius A. Burtea_, Jul 27 2019
results.author: _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Jul 25 2002
ext: Typo in example fixed by _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Mar 19 2010
